Sorry for this, I should have time to add `PrefetchingIter` this weekend.

I have a deadline on Friday. So please be patient. I will really appreciate that.

@rfarouni In my computer this revision solves the problem. Is it possible that you need to re-install the python package? Or update the rest part of MXNet to the latest version?

```
   lr_scheduler=None, arg_names=None):
super(Adam, self).__init__(rescale_grad, arg_names)
```

@tqchen, your workaround is incomplete becuase `-L/path/to/opencv/libs` only specifies the library path, but dose NOT tell the linker which libs to use. The linker still complains about objext missing in this case.

My workaround is to specify all OpenCV libraries manually, along with the lib path at the beginning. It makes the Makefile looks like:

```
# setup opencv
ifeq ($(USE_OPENCV), 1)
        CFLAGS += -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=1 -I/path/to/opencv/include
        LDFLAGS += -L/path/to/opencv/lib -lopencv_calib3d -lopencv_contrib -lopencv_core -lopencv_features2d -lopencv_flann -lopencv_gpu -lopencv_highgui -lopencv_imgproc -lopencv_legacy -lopencv_ml -lopencv_nonfree -lopencv_objdetect -lopencv_ocl -lopencv_photo -lopencv_stitching -lopencv_superres -lopencv_ts -lopencv_video -lopencv_videostab
        BIN += bin/im2rec
else
        CFLAGS+= -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=0
endif
```

@piiswrong Thanks! You mean using num_parts in the DataIter? I'm not sure how to grab parts 1-9. If I make a bunch of DataIters (one for each part) then I will have to loop through the 9 parts. I don't see a simple way to merge the 9 into one DataIter to use for training.

```
train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec = "data.rec",
    ...
    num_parts   = 10,
    part_index = 0
)
```
pooling doesn't maintain a map. It use == check to determine source in backward.
You probably need to write a python DataIter to wrap multiple ImageRecordIters on different parts.
Use mx.initializer.Load
since they have torch bindings, we should be able to call it directly through TorchModule. You are welcomed to submit a example PR on this.
This should be fixed on master branch now. Let me know if it isn't.

Hi, by debugging, I found that the problem comes with this line:

... = mx.model.load_checkpoint(args.prefix, args.epoch)

The reason must be that the pretrained model FCN8s_VGG16-0019.params or VGG_FC_ILSVRC_16_layers-0074.params contains information of GPU device number which does not match the client side. Please correct if necessary.

@colinpriest Just found this is a very simple error. It seems our documents are not clear enough.

`mx.model.load` takes two parameters, one for prefix, one for iteration.

You are providing only one parameter by using `mx.model.load(paste0(paste0(workingPath, "/systole"), iBest))`.

Can you try `mx.model.load(prefix = paste0(workingPath, "/systole"), iteration = iBest)` ?

Sorry that code doesn't work for me. I get the following error:

Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): Parameter scalar is not presented

@colinpriest Just confirmed this problem. But to be frank, I think this is an issue in IR kernel.

I will talk with these people.

Thanks. I haven't been able to get the script to run in R Studio yet because it can't find the cudart.so library. I suppose I will need to figure out why IPython can find the library, but R Studio cannot, so that I can switch to running mxnet in R Studio.

I guess you must be using the GPU.

The simplest solution: startup RStudio from terminal.

On Linux, just `rstudio`; on Mac, `/Applications/RStudio.app/Contents/MacOS/RStudio`
I guess rstudio must have some configuration on env variables, maybe consider add this to  a new R package trouble shootting section in here ttps://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/build.md
Thanks. Starting R Studio that way works! :-)
models with the same epoch number should be the same.
Theoretically, the CUDA path can be added in `~/.Renviron`. When R starts, it will try to find `~/.Renviron` and load it.

Thanks for your response.
Then why does it have different validation accuracy at same epoch between machines?
If partitioned val data causes that result, how can I know the validation accuracy for entire val data?
I'm wondering if there is some args for using partitioned val data or entire val data.

Because in BatchNorm network, moving-average/moving-variance is not synced. Different model has different moving parameters. You are supposed to update the moving parameter at the very end of training.

`setup.py` also rquires `libinfo.py` to report the proper path to `libmxnet.so` at packaging. Similar to the case that `train_mnist.py` is run for veryfying Python environment, intallation exits if libmxnet cannot be found in the default path.

I follow the guildes on [readthedoc](http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/build.html), spliting my installation into two parts: 1) building `libmxnet.so`; 2) buiding "apaters" for various languages. I really admire the separation of "libs" (maintained by adminstrators) and "lib callers" (maintained by users). However, rather than linking at runtime, Python's `setup.py` makes a copy of `libmxnet.so` into local dir, which may miss potential updates.
@tqchen @antinucleon @winstywang Looking forward to your answer. Thank you for your time!

This seems to be nice, can we make sure the priority of the path is maintained, e.g. First local path, then the LD_LIBRARY_PATH. 

The main purpose is that most users may not know how to install libmxnet, so we need to make sure things is correct for them. The most common use case is actually not doing installation at all and setup the PYTHONPATH, which enables quick updates of versions

currently it was not possible mainly because the validation accuracy eval metric is not presented to the epoch end callback. We can make some changes to the training function to expose more environement into the callback.
related to #798
@shuokay ImageRecorderIter is implemented in C++.  you can reference src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc

My modification adds `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` after `curr_path` and `api_path`. Libs in `curr_path` and `api_path` will be selected in priority as long as `dll_path` is searched in order. I run some tests to prove that system-wide and local `libmxnet.so` can co-exist, and the local one will be picked first.

I got to support various users too. My experiences are:
- **Build a stable/verified/high-performance lib and install it system-widely.** So the users don't bother to build them from scratch. For examples, atlas, openblas and mxnet.
- **Users can customize their virtual environment in `$HOME`.** [virtualenv](https://virtualenv.readthedocs.org)-like tools are essential. I favor it a lot more rather than `sudo pip`.
- **For advanced users, they can build everything (compilers, linkers, libs...) from scratch in $HOME.**
As mxnet is still in fast iteration, administrators hold the responsibility to update the system-wide `libmxnet.so` to date.
sounds good, this is merged.

actually, this code works for me without any change:

``` Python
data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = data, name='fc1', num_hidden=128)
act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, name='relu1', act_type="relu")
fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act1, name = 'fc2', num_hidden = 64)
act2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc2, name='relu2', act_type="relu")
fc3 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act2, name='fc3', num_hidden=10)
mlp = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc3, name = 'softmax')
#mysoftmax = NumpySoftmax()
#mlp = mysoftmax(data=fc3, name = 'softmax')

# data

#train, val = mnist_iterator(batch_size=100, input_shape = (784,))
train=mx.io.NDArrayIter(np.zeros((60000, 784)),label=np.zeros((60000,)),batch_size=100)

# train

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

model = mx.model.FeedForward(
    ctx = mx.cpu(), symbol = mlp, num_epoch = 20,
    learning_rate = 0.1, momentum = 0.9, wd = 0.00001)

model.fit(X=train)
```

`FeedForward` has an dictionary of ndarray, `arg_params`. Grab the parameters that you want and then convert them to numpy with `asnumpy()`.

So in this example (with my random seed):

``` python
{k:v.asnumpy() for k,v in model.arg_params.items()}
```

The linter used by dmlc is customized in https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/master/scripts/lint.py

We can add a customized option to disable the warning(e.g. function name)

I'm closing this issue. I couldn't figure out the data iterator but I wrote an EvalMetric to calculate the F1-Score in case people are looking for it in the future. It is hard coded to a specific class label though.

```
# coding: utf-8
from __future__ import absolute_import
from mxnet import metric
"""Online evaluation metric module."""

# from .base import string_types
import numpy

class F1(metric.EvalMetric):
    """Calculate F1-Score in terms of label 1"""
    def __init__(self):
        self.focusLabel = 1;
        super(F1, self).__init__('f1')

    def reset(self):
        self.tp = 0.0
        self.tn = 0.0
        self.fp = 0.0
        self.fn = 0.0
        super(F1, self)

    def get(self):
        try:
            precision = self.tp / (self.tp + self.fp)
            recall = self.tp / (self.tp + self.fn)
            return (self.name, 2 * (precision * recall) / (precision + recall))
        except:
            return (self.name, 0.0)

    def update(self, labels, preds):
        assert len(labels) == len(preds)
        for i in range(len(labels)):
            pred = preds[i].asnumpy()
            label = labels[i].asnumpy().astype('int32')
            pred_label = numpy.argmax(pred, axis=1)
            if label.shape[0] < pred_label.shape[0]:
                raise Exception("Predict label is more than data label? ")
            ### calc f1 here???!!!
            correct = pred_label == label[:pred_label.shape[0]]
            incorrect = pred_label != label[:pred_label.shape[0]]
            pos = pred_label == self.focusLabel
            neg = pred_label != self.focusLabel
            self.tp += numpy.sum(correct & pos)
            self.tn += numpy.sum(correct & neg)
            self.fp += numpy.sum(incorrect & pos)
            self.fn += numpy.sum(incorrect & neg)
            #print("tp = " + `self.tp`)
            #print("tn = " + `self.tn`)
            #print("fp = " + `self.fp`)
            #print("fn = " + `self.fn`)
```

```
        eval_metric = metric_f1.F1())
```

Looks like it's not compiled. Could you verify that torch_module.cc is compiled? I would suggest doing the following:
1) make clean_all and recompile
2) if it doesn't help, remove the mxnet folder and git clone a fresh repo from master and recompile. If you used python setup.py to install, also reinstall.
3) If still not working, add `TORCH_SRC += plugin/torch/torch_function.cc` after `TORCH_SRC = $(wildcard plugin/torch/*.cc)` in plugin/torch/torch.mk.
